issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

components.name: Query Processor
components.description: Tracks issues dealing with query processing.

fields.description:
Couple of issues:
- If the table sizes in MapJoinOperator.getParentDataSizes() are 0 for all tables, the largest small table selection is wrong and could select the large table (which results in NPE)

- The memory estimates can either divide-by-zero, or allocate 0 memory if the table size is 0. Try to come up with a sensible default for this.
fields.summary: Errors in Tez HashTableLoader when estimated table size is 0

you calling "desc.getParentDataSizes().get(pos)" two times...
Jason, can you "rbt post -g yes" and attach the link?

Patch v2 - removed redundant calls. Also changed the logic so that the memory for all hashtables are computed at the same time. If we have to do the fallback logic for one table, we should probably do it for all tables.
RB link at https://reviews.apache.org/r/34287/
would like to include to 1.2 branch

[~apivovarov]
Ditto for this one.
Mostafa, can you check RB link? I'm not sure it shows HIVE-10704.3.patch
Mostafa, can you check RB link? I'm not sure it shows HIVE-10704.3.patch
Done, command line rb was giving me some headache.

What is the negative side of dividing memory equally?
If we have 3 tables  (1KB, 0B, 2MB) how we should divided the memory? (Map<Integer, Long> tableMemorySizes). Is dividing memory equally the best solution?
Maybe we should treat 0B table as 1B table and give it minimum amount of the memory.

Table size of 0 is usually an error in the statistics and the actual table can be arbitrary big, so evenly dividing the memory is a much safer bet.
And in the case you mentioned above each hash table will get hive.auto.convert.join.noconditionaltask.size / 3.
By default this is Container size/3 which is more than enough for smaller tables.

Table size of 0 is usually an error in the statistics and the actual table can be arbitrary big, so evenly dividing the memory is a much safer bet.

By default this is Container size/3 which is more than enough for smaller tables.

[~apivovarov]
Any updates?

[~apivovarov]

[~apivovarov]
